metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse the emission or absorption of a photon by an atom in terms of a change in the electron energy state of the atom, with the difference in the states' energies being equal to the photon energy: E = hf = hc/λ

quantised_energy_levels.name: Quantised Energy Levels
quantised_energy_levels.formula: Electrons exist only in discrete energy states
quantised_energy_levels.correct: Electrons in atoms can only occupy specific, discrete energy levels. They cannot exist between these levels.

any energy value.error: This is the classical view, not the quantum view.
any energy value.fix: Electrons are restricted to quantised energy levels, like steps on a staircase.
any energy value.action: Think of a staircase: you can stand on step 1 or step 2, but not halfway between.

continuously variable.error: Quantum mechanics shows energy is discrete, not continuous.
continuously variable.fix: The quantisation of energy levels is a fundamental quantum property.
continuously variable.action: Review the Bohr model: electrons orbit only at specific radii with specific energies.

random positions.error: Electron positions have probability distributions but energies are fixed.
random positions.fix: While position is probabilistic, energy states are precisely defined.
random positions.action: Distinguish between position uncertainty and energy quantisation.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the fundamental concept of energy quantisation.
persistent.action: Study the hydrogen atom energy level diagram. Calculate differences between adjacent levels.

ground_state.name: Ground State
ground_state.correct: The ground state is the lowest energy level an electron can occupy in an atom. It is the most stable state.

highest energy level.error: Opposite. Ground state is the LOWEST energy.
highest energy level.fix: Ground = floor = lowest. Excited states are ABOVE ground state.
highest energy level.action: On an energy diagram, ground state is at the bottom.

zero energy.error: Ground state has a specific energy value, not zero.
zero energy.fix: In hydrogen, ground state is at 0 eV (or −13.6 eV depending on convention).
zero energy.action: Check the energy diagram: ground state has a defined energy value.

ionisation energy.error: Ionisation energy is the energy needed to REMOVE an electron.
ionisation energy.fix: Ground state is a bound state. Ionisation energy is the gap to freedom.
ionisation energy.action: Ionisation energy = energy from ground state to infinity.

persistent.gap: You confuse ground state with other energy concepts.
persistent.action: Label a hydrogen energy diagram: ground state at bottom, excited states above, ionisation at top.

excited_state.name: Excited State
excited_state.correct: An excited state is any energy level above the ground state. Excited states are unstable and decay to lower states.

stable configuration.error: Excited states are unstable, not stable.
stable configuration.fix: Electrons in excited states will spontaneously decay to lower levels.
stable configuration.action: Think of a ball on a hill: it wants to roll down. Excited electrons want to decay.

ground state with extra energy.error: An excited state is a different energy level, not the same level.
ground state with extra energy.fix: The electron moves to a different orbital, not just gains energy in place.
ground state with extra energy.action: On the energy diagram, the electron is on a different horizontal line.

ionised atom.error: Excited means raised energy, not lost electron.
ionised atom.fix: Ionisation removes the electron completely. Excitation just raises it to a higher level.
ionised atom.action: Excited = still bound but at higher energy. Ionised = electron escaped.

persistent.gap: You confuse excited states with ionisation or stability.
persistent.action: Draw the path: ground → excited → decay back to ground. This is different from ionisation.

emission_process.name: Photon Emission Process
emission_process.formula: Higher → lower energy level releases photon
emission_process.correct: When an electron transitions from a higher to a lower energy level, it emits a photon with energy equal to the energy difference.

absorbs a photon.fix: Downward transition = energy released = photon emitted.
absorbs a photon.action: Arrow pointing DOWN on energy diagram = emission.

electron escapes.fix: Emission keeps the electron bound but at a lower energy level.
electron escapes.action: After emission, the electron is still in the atom, just at a lower state.

energy is destroyed.fix: The lost electron energy becomes photon energy. Conservation of energy.
energy is destroyed.action: ΔE of electron = E of photon. Energy is transferred, not lost.

persistent.gap: You do not understand emission as energy release via photon.
persistent.action: Trace an emission: electron at n=3 drops to n=2, photon carries away the energy difference.

absorption_process.name: Photon Absorption Process
absorption_process.formula: Lower → higher energy level requires photon
absorption_process.correct: When an electron absorbs a photon with exactly the right energy, it transitions from a lower to a higher energy level.

emits a photon.error: Absorption takes in energy, emission releases it.
emits a photon.fix: Upward transition = energy gained = photon absorbed.
emits a photon.action: Arrow pointing UP on energy diagram = absorption.

any photon energy works.error: The photon energy must exactly match the gap.
any photon energy works.fix: Only photons with E = ΔE between levels are absorbed.
any photon energy works.action: This is why absorption spectra have specific lines, not a continuous band.

electron gains mass.error: Mass is not gained. Energy state changes.
electron gains mass.fix: The photon energy becomes electron potential energy in the higher level.
electron gains mass.action: The electron moves to a higher orbital, not a heavier one.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the selectivity of photon absorption.
persistent.action: Calculate which photon wavelengths hydrogen can absorb from its energy level diagram.

photon_energy_formula.name: Photon Energy Formula
photon_energy_formula.correct: Photon energy equals Planck's constant times frequency, or equivalently, Planck's constant times speed of light divided by wavelength.

E = hλ.error: Wavelength should be in the denominator with c.
E = hλ.fix: E = hc/λ. Longer wavelength = lower energy, so λ divides.
E = hλ.action: Check: red light (long λ) has less energy than blue (short λ). E ∝ 1/λ.

E = f/h.fix: E = hf. h is in the numerator.
E = f/h.action: Units: h is in J·s, f is in Hz (1/s). hf gives Joules.

E = mc².error: That's mass-energy equivalence, not photon energy.
E = mc².fix: Photons use E = hf. E = mc² is for rest mass energy.
E = mc².action: Photons are massless. They use E = hf, not E = mc².

persistent.gap: You do not know the photon energy formula.
persistent.action: Write E = hf = hc/λ. Calculate photon energy for 500 nm light.

energy_difference_formula.name: Energy Level Difference
energy_difference_formula.correct: The photon energy equals the absolute difference in energy between the two levels involved in the transition.

sum of energy levels.error: It is the difference, not the sum.
sum of energy levels.fix: Eph = |E2 − E1|. The photon carries the gap energy.
sum of energy levels.action: Subtract the two energy values. Take the absolute value.

ratio of energy levels.action: If E3 = 12.1 eV and E2 = 10.2 eV, then ΔE = 1.9 eV.

average of energy levels.error: The photon carries the difference, not the average.
average of energy levels.fix: Conservation of energy: electron loses ΔE, photon gains ΔE.
average of energy levels.action: Think of it as a jump: the photon energy is the height of the jump.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how to calculate photon energy from energy levels.
persistent.action: Practice: given E3 and E2, calculate the photon energy for a 3→2 transition.

emission_spectrum.name: Emission Line Spectrum
emission_spectrum.correct: An emission spectrum consists of bright coloured lines at specific wavelengths on a dark background, produced when excited atoms emit photons.

dark lines on bright background.fix: Emission = atoms giving off light = bright lines. Absorption = atoms taking in light = dark lines.
dark lines on bright background.action: Hot gas emits → bright lines. Cool gas in front of white light → dark lines.

continuous spectrum.error: Atomic spectra are discrete, not continuous.
continuous spectrum.fix: Quantised energy levels → discrete photon energies → line spectrum.
continuous spectrum.action: Continuous spectra come from hot solids. Line spectra come from hot gases.

all wavelengths present.error: Only specific wavelengths corresponding to energy gaps appear.
all wavelengths present.fix: Each bright line corresponds to a specific electron transition.
all wavelengths present.action: Count the lines: each represents a different ΔE value.

persistent.gap: You confuse emission and absorption spectra.
persistent.action: Draw both: emission (bright lines on dark) and absorption (dark lines on bright).

absorption_spectrum.name: Absorption Line Spectrum
absorption_spectrum.correct: An absorption spectrum consists of dark lines at specific wavelengths against a continuous bright background, produced when atoms absorb photons from white light.

bright lines on dark background.fix: Absorption = photons removed from white light = dark gaps.
bright lines on dark background.action: Fraunhofer lines in sunlight are absorption lines from the solar atmosphere.

completely dark spectrum.error: Only specific wavelengths are absorbed, not all of them.
completely dark spectrum.fix: Most wavelengths pass through. Only matching energies are absorbed.
completely dark spectrum.action: The background is bright; dark lines appear where absorption occurs.

random dark patches.error: The dark lines are at specific, predictable wavelengths.
random dark patches.fix: Dark lines appear exactly where emission lines would appear for that element.
random dark patches.action: Emission and absorption lines occur at the same wavelengths for a given element.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how absorption spectra form.
persistent.action: Trace the path: white light → cool gas → some wavelengths absorbed → dark lines in spectrum.

spectrum_element_identification.name: Spectral Fingerprints
spectrum_element_identification.correct: Every element produces a unique pattern of spectral lines because each element has unique energy level spacing.

all elements have identical spectra.error: Different elements have different energy level structures.
all elements have identical spectra.fix: The energy level diagram is unique to each element, giving unique line patterns.
all elements have identical spectra.action: Compare hydrogen and helium spectra: completely different line patterns.

spectra depend on temperature only.error: The wavelengths depend on the element, not just temperature.
spectra depend on temperature only.fix: Temperature affects which transitions occur, but the wavelengths are element-specific.
spectra depend on temperature only.action: Hot sodium and hot hydrogen emit different colours because they are different elements.

only hydrogen has a line spectrum.error: All elements produce line spectra when in gaseous atomic form.
only hydrogen has a line spectrum.fix: Every element has discrete energy levels and thus line spectra.
only hydrogen has a line spectrum.action: Look up spectra of helium, sodium, mercury: all have characteristic line patterns.

persistent.gap: You do not understand spectral fingerprinting.
persistent.action: Study the spectra of 3 elements. Note how line positions differ. This is how astronomers identify elements in stars.

metal_vapour_lamps.name: Metal Vapour Lamps
metal_vapour_lamps.formula: Excited gas atoms emit characteristic wavelengths
metal_vapour_lamps.correct: Metal vapour lamps work by electrically exciting metal atoms, which then emit photons at characteristic wavelengths as electrons decay.

thermal radiation.error: Metal vapour lamps use electronic excitation, not thermal glow.
thermal radiation.fix: Electrical discharge excites atoms. Decay produces specific emission lines.
thermal radiation.action: A sodium lamp glows yellow-orange due to specific sodium emission lines.

continuous light emission.error: They emit discrete wavelengths, appearing as dominant colours.
continuous light emission.fix: Sodium lamps emit mainly at 589 nm (yellow). Not all colours are present.
continuous light emission.action: Under a sodium lamp, red and blue objects look strange because those wavelengths are weak.

absorption of light.error: Lamps emit light, they do not absorb it.
absorption of light.fix: The lamp's function is to produce light through emission.
absorption of light.action: Electrical energy → atomic excitation → photon emission → visible light.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how discharge lamps work.
persistent.action: Research sodium vapour lamps. Note the dominant 589 nm yellow emission line.

ionisation_energy.name: Ionisation Energy
ionisation_energy.correct: Ionisation energy is the minimum energy required to completely remove an electron from an atom in its ground state.

energy to excite to first level.error: That's excitation energy, not ionisation energy.
energy to excite to first level.fix: Ionisation removes the electron. Excitation just raises it to a higher bound level.
energy to excite to first level.action: Ionisation energy for hydrogen = 13.6 eV. First excitation energy = 10.2 eV.

energy released when electron leaves.error: Ionisation requires energy input, not output.
energy released when electron leaves.fix: You must supply energy to overcome the attraction to the nucleus.
energy released when electron leaves.action: The electron is bound. Work must be done to free it.

ground state energy.error: Ionisation energy is the gap from ground state to freedom, not the ground state value itself.
ground state energy.fix: Ionisation energy = 0 eV − (ground state energy) = 13.6 eV for hydrogen.
ground state energy.action: On the energy diagram, measure from ground state to the ionisation limit at top.

persistent.gap: You confuse ionisation energy with other energy values.
persistent.action: On a hydrogen energy diagram, mark: ground state, ionisation limit, ionisation energy as the gap between them.

sentences.text: An electron drops from the n = 4 state (E = 12.8 eV) to the n = 2 state (E = 10.2 eV). The emitted photon has energy {{d1}} eV, which can be converted to {{d2}} using E = hf.

d3.tooltip: Rearrange E = hc/λ to solve for λ.

d4.tooltip: If λ is larger, what happens to E = hc/λ?

energy_levels.title: Mastering Energy Level Concepts
energy_levels.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of atomic energy structure.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that electrons can have any energy. In reality, the {{d1}} of electron energies in atoms explains why spectra consist of {{d2}} rather than continuous bands.

d4.tooltip: What property of the nucleus affects energy level spacing?

emission.title: Complete Understanding of Emission

absorption.title: Complete Understanding of Absorption
absorption.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of photon absorption processes.
